text: thanks very much for that introduction and thanks for having me today
so the title of my talk is wireless power transfer and rf energy harvesting new options for
system designers so i am going to be talking about ambient rf as indicated and i'll also be talking
about some other rf power transfer schemes
let's see now the reason i call it new options for system designers is
not because i'm going to be talking very much about design but one of the things i think is most important and interesting about wireless
power is the the different design options that it will create so before i
get started i'd just like to acknowledge my graduate students and an alumni
this is a lancet sample who is my first phd student uh he graduated about a month after i
started at uw because i've been work we've been working together at intel for about five years before that
so i thought if i could only crank out one phd student a month i'd really be have something going so far it's slowed
down unfortunately now before i get into the meat of the talk i'll just give you a little overview of my group
i call the group sensor systems and from the name you might think that that's all about inventing new sensors
and we do do some of that which is what i have labeled down here at the bottom but we're also interested in all the
other things around that that it takes uh you know that you need to take an isolated sensor and turn it
into a usable system so that involves communicating with with uh sensors
and what most of what i'm going to be talking about today is actually about powering uh sensor and actuator systems um
we're also interested in various applications of sensor systems so things like ubiquitous computing uh
medical applications robotics and i'll actually talk about some of some of each of those
but the bulk of the talk today is going to be about our work in wireless power whoops the b
key and i will unpack these acronyms as we go these are several different systems
that we've developed so before i talk about some of the specific
systems why wireless power i mean in some ways it seems so obvious that you don't even need to motivate it but it's
kind of interesting to think about what are the specific benefits partially because different applications are kind
of benefiting from different things so one of them is is cord elimination so here's a mess of cords that you see
obviously wireless data can help eliminate quite a few cords but it doesn't may not eliminate all of
them of course one way to eliminate the power cord at least some of the time is to use batteries
so battery elimination is another potential benefit of wireless power that works in some applications and if
you think about what are the benefits of getting rid of batteries more specifically uh one is your device can potentially be
you know have a perpetual lifetime if it's getting the rf kind of live then you may be able to eliminate the
battery altogether and not worry about it dying if you can eliminate the battery you can
reduce the size often so sometimes we're in a volume constraint situation and of course you can get rid of weight
as well and you'll see some applications today where the weight constraint is really the benefit of wireless power
or we're removing the weight constraint now this is one where i'm not sure i have the best uh
description of it but the two images you see here are are images of the the monolith from 2001
a space odyssey so one way to think about this benefit is you know imagine you have you know
future version of the iphone here's here's an existing iphone it has quite a few connectors and buttons and
things but you can imagine if you have wireless power and wireless data and if we sense you
know buttons using some kind of capacitive rf sensing technique then you could imagine making something
like a phone that's just a completely sealed uh monolithic box that has
you know no ports or no no features whatsoever and actually you'll see several applications today where
what you might call boundary integrity is is the key benefit so it's not just for consumer electronics but if you start thinking
about biomedical applications that's a case where you don't want extra ports being put in your body
and we'll see some other examples of that too finally here's uh i've got emperor
palpatine from star wars helping us out here for this one i was talking to some nasa people about
the possibility of transferring power wirelessly between spacecraft and so there the
benefit is non-contact energy transfer so you know if you have these spacecraft that can
be sent off accidentally with small amounts of force then the fact that you don't have to use
force to make and break connections is potentially a nice benefit so these things are all
similar and related but as we go i'll point out when we're
taking advantage of different these different benefits now when i think about the space of
wirelessly powered systems this is one of the ways i like to carve it up so i have one axis which is
far field versus near field far field literally means further away probably in terms of rf
more than a wavelength away and i also have some near field work
and the far field systems tend to be smaller amounts of power longer range the near field systems are
larger amounts of power shorter range and the other the other axis
that i use is is you could call it wild or planted and that is you know is this power that
we deliberately transmitted with the intention of collecting again later or is this power that was already out there
for some reason that we found and used and that's what i'm calling wild
so each of these you know we've explored several of these boxes and
these are the names of the systems that uh occupy uh each box and as we go i'll
talk about the specifics so one final uh sort of piece of
introduction is if you think about the far field systems the thing that has made these possible
is energy efficiency scaling so if you look at this plot not very carefully it looks like
kind of a moore's law plot that you've probably seen many times the horizontal axis has you know time in decades but in this
case the vertical axis instead of being number of transistors we can put on a on a chip or in a certain area this is
actually in number of instructions we can execute per micro joule so this is a plot of energy efficiency
and if you look if you compare say eniac to a 2009 laptop there's been a factor of about a
trillion improvement in energy efficiency and that is what is an enable enabling these far-field
low-power applications that i'm going to show you it's also kind of interesting to note that there's quite a bit of room for improvement if
you think of the brain as a as an example estimates of its energy efficiency put
it out here you know several more orders of magnitude beyond where our
digital computing is today this doesn't mean that we don't get brains until 2040
which sometimes is what people interpret this to be it just means that our technology will not be as energy
efficient as brains until then now this is a related plot the upper trace here i took uh
micro processors and microcontrollers and plotted their energy efficiency in
the same units instructions per micro joule and then the bottom trace is if you
think about a particular workload that we're going to execute using one of these microcontrollers like let's say make a sensor value make a
sensor measurement encode the data maybe compute a crc and then
something like that and then you ask well you know what's the total energy it takes to do that workload and
we assume we can transmit a certain amount of power wirelessly so you know the law allows us to
transmit a certain amount that power falls off as one over r squared
with distance so what that means is that if i pick a particular workload and i look
assume that i'm going to be able to execute it on increasingly efficient hardware that means the range at which i'll be
able to execute that workload is going up exponentially too but
because of the one over r squared falloff the slope of this range scaling curve
is is one half of the energy efficiency curve so this explains why you know 10 or 15
years ago people were able to start making far field uhf rfid tags
you know before that the energy efficiency wasn't there to do this but the more exciting thing
about it is it means that the various things that we can do at fairly short range today like 5 five to ten feet if this energy
efficiency scaling trend continues we'll be able to do it longer and longer range and so i think that will take some of
the things i'm going to show you from being kind of interesting novelties to being something that is very practical
that you could really use in a variety of applications so the first system that i'm going to
describe is called wisp which stands for wireless identification and sensing platform
and this is basically a uhf rfid tag that we created from scratch so typically the way rfid
works is there's a reader that emits well in this case 915 megahertz
rf carrier the tag rectifies that rf energy and uses it to
power some digital logic the way the tag communicates back to the reader instead of having its own radio
radio transmitter oscillator all that stuff it uses a technique called backscatter
where it simply changes the reflection coefficient of this antenna so it has a little
transistor that it shorts to short the two branches of the antenna together or can choose not to short them
and that generates a reflection of the reader's signal so an analogy would be the reader's kind
of like a flashlight and the tag is sort of like a mirror and you know by moving the mirror you
can affect how much light gets reflected back so rather than having to have your own ability to create light uh the tag just
does this backscatter which is as you can imagine it's it's very energy efficient because it's not generating any
any rf signals it's just reflecting them so the wisp
has a microcontroller which can actually execute general purpose programs we can also put sensors on it
and so it functions the same way as an rfid tag in the sense that it's
wirelessly powered and it uses very efficient backscatter communication but other than that it's a lot more capable
so what i'm going to show you in this video is an early wisp so this over here is a
rfid reader it's been dressed up to look like a picture frame and in my hand is a three axis
accelerometer wisp so i'll play the movie here i'm working
the remote control with my other hand which is why i'm looking very strange there so now as i
tilt this stack of boards back and forth the accelerometer is is seeing gravity showing up on the
three different channels the x y and z channel of the accelerometer the microcontroller is
reading the the values the analog voltages that are coming out of that accelerometer
it's encoding them computing a crc and doing this back scatter communication to encode the tilt for the reader which
is then drawing this this picture so you can think of this as a kind of like an input device and in fact this
accelerometer is the same thing it's in the wii game controller again the key kind of interesting thing
about this is that there's no battery in that stack of boards and the other thing i should emphasize sometimes
people look at this and they think it's some kind of antenna polarization trick or something like that you know it's nothing like that that
that's a system that's being you know powered by the rf and it's it's digitally
communicating via backscatter so
in terms of what's inside that here's a block diagram so many of the blocks here are the same as
what you'd find in a conventional rfid tag the difference is the stuff on the right
so working in from the left there's an antenna some impedance matching
power harvesting circuitry that turns the rf from the reader into usable dc voltage there's a regulator voltage
regulator oops i keep hitting that
and then these two components at the top and bottom are also something you'd find in a conventional rfid tag
demodulator extracts data from the reader so the reader is not always on it actually modulates
its amplitude in order to encode downlink data data from the reader to the tag and
then the modulator is simply a transistor that is used to short the the antenna as
i was describing before so these blocks over here on the right are the pieces that are unique to the wisp so there's a microcontroller with
adc and then external sensors and the state machine instead of being implemented in
discrete dedicated logic is is actually software and that means we can program it
which has a lot of exciting uh possibilities so here's a view in a little more detail
of the blocks inside the wisp so here's the rectifier that we were using at that time
the demodulator and some power management and i'll talk just a little bit about each of those blocks
so this is actually a simulation of the of a one-stage rectifier
and in this visualization color corresponds to voltage and dot velocity is current so it's kind of
nice that you can see them both separately so over here would be the you know the input signal from the
antenna so you can see these dots are just going going back and forth so it's a ac or rf
signal and then if you look at the the dots on the diodes say look at the bottom diode you can see
that the dots are only going up so that's you know of course what the diode does it only allows current to pass in one direction
and if you kind of look at it you can see it's behaving sort of like a check valve
or something like that where again the current only flows one direction and so you know driving it with an ac signal at
this point in this configuration causes a dc output up here so if you
look at the dots up here they're only going one direction because of the rectification rectifying action
of the diodes okay and then in this simulation we've
sort of ganged three of those stages together and what that gives us is voltage gain
so this point here where i'm putting the mouse is in this simulation is giving us 26
volts of dc in this this point here this after the second stage we're getting something
like 52 volts of dc and after the third stage we're getting 78 volts so these component values
obviously aren't specific to rfid but this gives you the idea and the reason it's important to get some
voltage gain is that even if we have sufficient power to do the job that we want to do
if we don't have enough voltage the electronics the microcontroller won't turn on at all
so often range is constrained by voltage and so that's that's why you're we're
interested in ways to to boost voltage this shows the rectification efficiency
as a function of input power so you can see it peaks here at about 32 or three percent something like this for
that particular rectifier now this shows kind of the behavior of the power management block
which is sort of interesting so the red trace is the harvested voltage so starting from zero
this thing is waking up and then these two lines up here are two thresholds that we
have set so there's a supervisor which is a piece of hardware that detects a certain voltage and then generates an interrupt
when that threshold is exceeded so the microcontroller sleeps until this upper threshold has been
exceeded once there's enough voltage the microcontroller wakes up
does its sensing does its communication that causes it to of course spend energy which
decreases the the available voltage and it'll you know keep doing that until
it gets to this lower threshold when it hits that lower threshold it'll go to sleep and start charging back up
again which is this upward trace now if if the tag were further from the reader
there'd be less rf energy coming in so this upward slope would become shallower so it would take
longer to get back to the the charged up state and then because the tag is you know obeying the rfid protocol and so
forth it's going to spend energy at basically the same rate so the downward slopes here are always going to be about the
same but what you'll see is this simple mechanism of having these two thresholds
has the net effect of causing the tag to delay in proportion to the you know
power available and so on average the power expended by the tag ends up being exactly the same as the
power available so it's just a very simple mechanism that kind of has nice properties now
one of the things a lot of people are working on now is more sophisticated schemes that use software because you know the size of
the job that you're executing can affect the way you want to do this duty cycling if i have
some job that takes longer to execute then you know the amount of time i have available here
then i may not be able to finish before the uh before the tag goes to sleep so various
ways of doing adaptive thresholds is something that uh you know many of my colleagues are
interested in uh now okay so
we built the wisp uh the very first wisp and say the accelerometer that i showed you
i think that was actually 2006. we we hardened it quite a bit further
than what you saw in that video and then we made it available to academic collaborators through a program we called the wisp challenge so people
could propose applications we would send them uh send them some wisps and i'll show
you some of the applications people have done so this one was kind of a surprising one this was with some
neutrino physicists in italy they're working on an underwater
neutrino telescope that's going to be a kilometer on a side under the mediterranean sea it consists
of 10 000 glass spheres which you can see here that have photomultiplier tubes inside
them so what they're looking for is when a neutrino comes through the water it generates a flash of light and they want to detect the sequence of flashes
and then figure out where the neutrinos came from now their thought is as long as they're
going to all the trouble to deplete these ten thousand uh glass spheres under the sea
they might as well try to do some oceanography as well so they took the wisp and they potted it on the
outside of the sphere then they put a small rfid reader inside the sphere and found that they could successfully
make temper temperature measurements that way so in this case the benefit to them was not that they wanted to
sense at long range but they had this this boundary which is the glass sphere that is not not easy to breach so they
they can't just add additional uh ports in this thing because you know that'll cause
failures and or it's and it's expensive to to to create uh completely new uh
you know housings like this plus each port that you have is further risk so this is actually one of the examples
of of boundary integrity where the the key benefit of wireless power in this case is just getting through this
one centimeter of glass which is a you know it's a high there's a high pressure gradient across
it and and so you don't want to have additional ports in that in that glass
now here's a completely different application my student a lanson sample realized that
it's possible to add buttons to rfid tags essentially capacitive buttons to using
the same antenna you know using the antenna for for the rf purposes but also for the
the capacitive sensing so what you see down here is the signal applied to
to the antenna in the case that you're not touching it and then when you touch it you increase
the capacitance so the the microcontroller is charging and discharging in a certain pattern where if you add the capacitance by
touching it it takes longer to charge and discharge so this gets stretched out but you can see that
you know these are the rf functions they're still unimpaired so the neat thing about this is that you can imagine
you know taking an rfid chip that still just has two wires two ports but starting to add user
interface to it so you know here's one button but you can imagine doing a more sophisticated version of this that would be a keypad
so for things like credit card you know you could have a pin that you enter and it would all be
implemented just using the basic rfid capabilities here's another this is a more recent
application so this is measuring eeg using the wisp so artem here
created an eeg circuit that uh he interfaced to the wisp so again this
is this is wirelessly uh powered and red and you know there are now input devices
you know gaming systems that uh that work you know that use eeg none of them are
wirelessly powered at the moment now one of the challenges we discovered uh when we did this
is that um you know the reader is emitting this large rf signal and it's and it's
modulating it the the very sensitive voltage measurements that you're making here for the eeg tend to pick up the reader
so in this case right now you multiplex between the sensing and
the communication but i think this is an interesting challenge for the future you know the rfid protocols were
designed just for this tag communication application uh they weren't designed for sensing so it's
interesting to think about you know can we redesign the entire protocol so that we can do sensing communication
power simultaneously it's interesting to think about how these different functions trade off with
one another now here was a completely different application of the wisp that took us by
surprise when we built the wisp we thought it was all about sensing but my colleague kevin foo
is very interested in security and cryptography and it turns out there's a there's a whole community of people working on rfid
cryptography for things like payment transactions and things like that and in the past there had you know before the
wisp there had never been a way to actually implement applications and write code that would run on an rfid tag
because they were just black boxes so working with kevin we we implemented the rc5 encryption algorithm on the wisp
and so that's interesting first because we were able to just write software to do
something on a tag also the conventional wisdom had been that because rfid tags are so power
constrained you need special low power cryptography but most of those low power cryptographic schemes were
broken and here we just used a conventional you know full strength
uh crypto crypto system um and i think you know if you look at the energy efficiency scaling that i showed at the
beginning that's part of the reason why you know this makes more and more sense as time
goes on and people have gone on to implement many other crypto systems uh using the wisp in fact here here's another example
so intel uh commercialized the wisp design for an application in brazil called
cineav which is basically a tolling system a kind of augmented tolling system so in many places
you have these tags that you put in your windshield that are essentially rfid tags that are used that
are used to pay tolls well in brazil they want to use that sort of system for many other things as well
they want to use it for buying gas so you buy drive into the gas station and you're just billed for the gas that you
use or you go into the parking lot and the payment happens that way so to make that happen they wanted a lot
more security than the conventional rfid uh offered so there's their standard
calls for using the aes the advanced encryption standard and so for us we were able to just write
some software run it on the tag and then we had an aes compliance system
the other people working on this the other competitors had to design digital logic and you know
took a long time so our team was able to get to market a lot faster
because of this software approach so another sort of application
that my student eve zao has been working on recently is doing ultrasonic localization
uh implemented on the wisps so localization is a problem that
people in rfid have been interested in for a long time because you know given rf propagation it's
difficult to localize rfid tags it's difficult to find out where exactly the tag is because
you know because of the you know strange ways that that rf propagation
changes when someone comes into the room or a door opens or closes things like that it's hard to use the rf signals
themselves to precisely localize something so here the idea is to combine ultrasonic localization with
with rf so the idea is that the rfid reader now will emit some ultrasound the tags
have ultrasound detectors the rf signal tells all the tags to start their timers
and the rf propagation is practically instantaneous but it takes a long time for the for the
ultrasound to get there because you know rf propagates at one nanosecond per foot whereas
acoustic signals propagate at one millisecond per foot um so each tag sits there
waiting for the ultrasound pulse to come in measures when the when the ultrasound arrives and then transmits that data
back to the reader using backscatter and then the reader can localize the tags that way so that
mechanism of dual rf ultrasound had been proposed before for example by the by the crickets and mit project but the
the nice thing here is that uh this is you know battery free and uh also integrates with rfid infrastructure
so that if you have some kind of tracking system and readers you could potentially use this fairly easily
okay now here's a very new project this is going to be coming out at the yuba comp conference
in september so the board that you see on the right we call the nfc wisp
so this is nfc's near field communication and this is a standard that's being built into many phones now
so you know android some android phones have this for example so essentially the phone is an nfc reader so that
this is 13 megahertz or you know hf rather than uhf but so this board here
can receive power from the phone and transmit data bi-directionally oops so
what we've done over here is we've integrated the nfc wisp with an e-ink display so now you can take your phone put it up
to this display thing shake the phone the phone
powers the powers the nfc wisp with display sends in this case an image of the
screen so it captures a screenshot which gets written onto the ink display and because
the e-ink is by stable once you've once you've set each pixel black or white they stay without any further power
so the the by stable display is kind of a nice match to wireless power when you may or may not have power available
when you have the power you set the display then the power goes away and the display changes
so there are probably many other applications for things like this you can imagine having something on your door which is a kind of yank sign that you
could interact with with your phone maybe it would also have a far-field uhf rfid interface so you could you know set
an appointment or a note on the right on this display on the door and then it would also propagate to the rest
of the building and calendar systems and things like that so i think this is this is going to be
an interesting set of things to do and i also wanted to highlight this because this is the first
example i've showed so far of a display that is that is wirelessly powered now all the
wisps that i showed you so far the most recent one was the we called it the wisp 4.0 a little
advertisement we're coming out with the wisp 5.0 which will have longer range and more
memory and so forth and we're going to do a similar project a similar program to the wisp challenge
in fact my colleague david weatherall and i just got a million dollar nsf grant through the
let's see what's it called computing research infrastructure program to make these and readers available to the
research community so that's something that hopefully by the end of the summer we'll have
available okay so now oops i'm going to talk about another
recent project where we wanted to go to much higher data rates for uh for
a wirelessly powered sensor system so what i showed you uh with with that first wisp video was an
accelerometer that was being measured maybe 20 20 or 30 times a second what i'm going
to show you here is a way to do audio which is much higher data rate sensing but all using far field
you know battery free sensing and so for inspiration here we we're going back to something called the
great seal bug which probably some of you know the story of this uh this device was invented
probably by the uh the inventor leon theremin who was kidnapped from the united states taken
back to russia forced to work on bugs seems like this is the bug or one of the bugs that he came up with so
some soviet boy scout equivalents gave this great seal of the united states to the
american ambassador they measured it didn't seem to be emitting any rf signals
didn't have any batteries so they thought it was okay so he hung it in his office for seven years and it turned out that it
was a bug the whole time and the way that it worked was actually a version of backscatter
so the audio in the room would cause this diaphragm to vibrate
some kind of metallized membrane and that would change the reflection coefficient of this antenna
so a truck would be parked outside the antenna the the embassy broadcasting microwave
you know rf uh in um and based on the sound in the room the the amount of of rf reflected would
change so the audio in the room was essentially modulating uh the the back scattered rf
so that's basically what led to backscatter communication as as as i was showing you earlier
so in the conventional wisp we have a transistor that's used to short the two branches of the antenna together so we're just doing
binary you know two levels of backscatter but what what we're proposing here or
what we've done here is to take a conventional wisp then add a microphone and and an analog
switch in series with the mic so now we can talk to the wisp in the conventional way it has a unique
id we can send it a command to enable the the microphone which case it closes the switch and now
the microphone is going to be directly connected to the antenna and so it's going to go into an analog
backscatter mode where it's actually backscattering audio in the same way that this great seal bug did so what you see in the blue up here
this this part is the digital communication digital traffic between the tag and reader and then
when it goes into analog backscatter mode you see this trace here so this is actually audio
that is being backscattered and now i'm going to play you two samples the first was uh from a distance of
0.7 meters so that the microphone uh and the wisp is is here the reader is
is you know less than a meter away oops sorry okay here comes the audio now
here's something we hope you'll really like sorry that was too loud anybody
recognize that rocky and bullwinkle now here it is from
seven meters away oops
so a lot more noise and sounds like an am radio because it is you know am modulation
but i think that you know the thing that's exciting about this is now we have a microphone that has no batteries
that we can read from you know fair distance away
and so that's a much more demanding sensing challenge than than what i showed you earlier with the 20 uh
samples per second uh sensing and there's obviously a lot of room for
improvement with that but but i think it's an exciting result
okay so everything i've showed you so far was example of wisp and in all those
systems we were deliberately transmitting the rf power so we had a reader whose purpose was to put out the rf power we
were going to use but it turns out that using similar rectification techniques we can capture
power from ambient sources like tv or cell phones so we call this project wireless ambient
radio power and the image you see on the left is that this is a tv tower in seattle
uh which puts out a megawatt uh rf energy and then this is a commercial
wideband tv antenna uhf is the band that we're using and
we're using essentially the same rectifier that that that was used in the wisp and in this example we're just powering
a commercial off the shelf kitchen thermometer so that was a first just proof of
concept the map that you see on the right shows the location of that one megawatt
tower and the inner circle is the range at which you'd expect to be able to
get about a hundred micro watts and then if this further circle you'd expect to be able to get 25
microwatts and the image you see up here is a newer harvester using just uh you know a dipole antenna
so rather than this large wideband antenna this antenna is tuned to one particular frequency
i think it's like 739 megahertz something like that but it's and it's obviously a lot
smaller than the the broadband antenna
so more recently we've been able to harvest from cell phone towers so
the map over here on the right is the university of washington campus so there's a large fountain here and on top of this
building there's a cell phone tower you know array of antennas
at these green locations where we were able to harvest power from from those base
cell phone base stations do a sensor measurement and transmit
data a short distance using like a zigbee like radio and then at these two locations the red
locations it didn't work which my theory is it's maybe some sort of a
multi-path you know bounce off this water but we haven't investigated that yet
so in this case you know the range is is a lot less than with tv here we're looking at 200 meters something like
that but you know sometimes people ask well is tv going to go away
broadcast tv maybe it will i don't think cell phone signals are ever going to go away
but i think the density will increase and increase so this is maybe not quite enough power to
do everything that you want well clearly it's not quite enough to do everything that you want now but if cells cells get smaller and smaller
and more and more numerous this may become increasingly practical as a way to power electronics now the way that we did uh
the way we were able to to operate using the cell phone power
actually required a new type of harvester so this is our old harvester i showed you a simulation of something
like this a few minutes ago you can see it's just a bunch of diodes schottky diodes in this case
what we found is that when the signals get very very small corresponding to be being very far away
from the reader you do better having just a single stage of rectification
followed by a dc to dc converter to get the voltage gain
and so that allowed us this new design allowed us to go from negative 9 dbm sensitivity or
corresponding to 125 microwatts as the minimum that you would need to operate
that allowed us to move to negative 18 dbm sensitivity which corresponds to something like 15 micro watts
or in terms of range that's you know 3x range improvement so again just to
emphasize the the various constraints you know power in some sense is not really a
constraint because the tag can sleep for as long as it wants in principle to accumulate
enough energy to do the thing it needs to do so if you're willing to adjust duty cycle as much as you want
you can always in principle match your power uh required to power available on the other
hand voltage is more of a hard constraint if you don't have enough voltage the thing won't turn on at all and no
matter how long you're willing to wait the thing won't operate so it's important to be able to to get
the voltage gain that you need on the other hand one of the nice things
about the voltage constraint is that you know voltage is not a conserved quantity so you know this box is
actually generating more voltage than uh then you're providing to it
so that's that's one of the kind of engineering uh opportunities is is to find ways to to
get voltage gain when you need it now this plot here in
the middle shows that the horizontal axis is is basically range in meters so this is 10 kilometers 20
kilometers the blue is the old harvester design and the green is the new harvester design
so you can see that the old design basically stops working all together at
about 10 kilometers whereas this new design with the dc-dc converter will work well beyond
20 kilometers the other thing is that short range the the old design is actually better

coil to coil so now i'll explain a little bit about how that works
so the coils on the transmit side are represented here so it's several
turns of copper and that has some inductance and some capacitance it has a resonant frequency determined
by these two values the received side also is a tuned circuit tuned to the same
frequency and as it happens we inductively couple
into those which isn't too important for our purposes but if you work out the whole
transfer function for the system you get this kind of messy expression and in a minute i'm going to show you a
plot of that that is going to make it much more intuitive a key point is we can figure out how
this thing behaves and now i'm going to show you a mechanical analog for this that will give you some
intuition onto how it works so this is a simulation of the
mass and spring system you see up here so the transmit coil is analogous to a single mass and a
spring which has a certain natural frequency determined by the mass and the spring constant just the way the
lc circuit is determined by the the l and c values the received side is also a another mass
in spring and then the magnetic field that couples those things together that we're actually using to transfer the power
is like this spring here now it turns out when you have a system like this with
two coupled resonators instead of having one resonant frequency
there are actually two resonant frequencies or two normal modes so this plot what you're seeing
simulated here is the in phase mode where the two masses are moving together
and then now i'm switching it to the anti-phase mode where they're always opposite
and those two modes are both you know resonant frequencies at which the system
absorbs energy very efficiently and the frequencies of those two modes
are different from one another and it turns out that the tighter i make the spring in the
center the greater the splitting which means the greater the difference in frequency
between the in-phase mode and the anti-phase mode and so now i'm going to show you a plot
of that transfer function this is it right here so
the vertical axis is efficiency this left axis here is distance between
the transmit coil and receive coil and then this axis over here is frequency so
at very short distances we have a large degree of splitting so when the transmitter and receiver are
close to each other that corresponds to a very tight spring in the in the mechanical analog
and now if you pick a distance like let's say 10 centimeters and trace across here
you can see we're going to hit one peak first which is the
the in phase mode and then we're going to hit another peak over here which is the anti-phase mode
so this surface is sort of the key to how this wireless power system works
so the key observation is that if we had a control system that could pick the frequency
as the distance changed then we could stay on top of this ridge so even as a transmitter and receiver
move back and forth from one another we're going to adjust the frequency to stay on top of that ridge
and what that means is that we're going to get relatively constant efficiency so if i were viewing this v-shaped
plateau from the side it looks fairly flat on top so
the key idea here is that as the transmitter receive move with respect to one another either
in distance or orientation turns out to to work as well
we're going to adjust the system properties to keep the efficiency basically constant and the thing that surprised me about
this at first is that you know when i had thought about wireless power systems uh in the past i
always just kind of assume that the further away the receiver is the less power you get but what this shows is that in this
regime inside this this red box if this if the control system is working
correctly then we actually get constant efficiency uh even as the the geometry changes
and so now i'm going to show you a movie the first section of the movie we don't have auto tuning on and in the

rf signals with the human body and they have they call the virtual family
which is basically they took cat scans of uh you know four four people uh uh different sizes and shapes

this you know from the initial uh work it looks like something like 50 watts
is uh is safe um now obviously for every specific
situation you you have to look at you know every specific application you'd have to look at it more carefully and see
if if you satisfy the various regulations but you know the reason you go to such
high power levels is because the transmitter is mostly generating a magnetic field which
basically doesn't interact with your body when you have an electric field the water molecules in your body are
electrically polar and they orient to the electric field that's of course how a microwave oven heats up
food or water so to the extent you can have just a magnetic field you're
basically able to transfer power without interacting with the body of course the changing magnetic
field generates a secondary electric field like eddy currents and so forth and those are the things that
ultimately limit the power level that you can go to so now i'll tell you about some of the

individual neural spike measurement systems so there are arrays of essentially

when you take a seashell and put it up to your ear you hear the sound of the sea of course that's not really the sea what

further from your head the properties of that filter change so we're going to do the same thing we take
a pipe instead of a c shell put a microphone in it and as that pipe approaches an object
